discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
No, response-wrapping tokens are per request:
https://developer.hashicorp.com/vault/docs/concepts/response-wrapping#response-wrapping-token-creation

questions.question_text: You can use a response-wrapping token more than once for as long as it has not expired.

discussion.content:
CE

This is the right answer

Selected Answer: CE
C & E are correct as per https://developer.hashicorp.com/vault/docs/secrets/kv/kv-v2

choices.A: Enables the secrets engine at path kv2/
choices.C: Enables the secrets engine at path kv/

questions.question_text: Which statement describes the results of this command: $ vault secrets enable -version=2 kv (Choose two.)
Which of these are names of the replication methods available in Vault Enterprise? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
Disaster Recovery Replication & Performance Replication.

questions.question_text: What attributes are unique to batch tokens? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
ABD

Can't be renewable
Can't be periodic
Are not persisted

comments.content: I think you have marked option C instead of B, although the link clearly indicates B (I think it was just a mistake in the marking)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: ACD
Check Service vs Batch Token table here https://developer.hashicorp.com/vault/tutorials/tokens/batch-tokens

questions.question_text: You have manually created some usernames and passwords for a Microsoft SQL database on Azure, and need to store these credentials in Vault. What secrets engine should you use for this?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is correct as you manually created credentials and didn't originally enable the Database Secrets Engine with the MSSQL plugin to create dynamic ones.
